t: Isaiah 1
The*p vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and*i Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
The Wickedness of Judah
Hear,*pn O heavens, and give ear, O earth! For*ld the Lord*s has spoken: “I*ld have nourished and brought up children, And*ld they have rebelled against Me;
The*ld ox knows its owner And*ld the donkey its master’s crib; But*ild Israel does not know, My*ld people do not consider.”

Alas,*ln sinful nation, A*ld people laden with iniquity, A*ld brood of evildoers, Children*ld who are corrupters! They*ld have forsaken the Lord,*s They*ld have provoked to anger The*ld Holy One of Israel, They*ld have turned away backward.
Why*ln should you be stricken again? You*ld will revolt more and more. The*ld whole head is sick, And*ld the whole heart faints.

From*ld the sole of the foot even to the head, There*ild is*i no soundness in it, But*ild wounds and bruises and putrefying sores; They*ld have not been closed or bound up, Or*ld soothed with ointment.
Your*ln country is*i desolate, Your*ld cities are*i burned with fire; Strangers*ld devour your land in your presence; And*ld it*i is*i desolate, as overthrown by strangers.
So*ld the daughter of Zion is left as a booth in a vineyard, As*ld a hut in a garden of cucumbers, As*ld a besieged city.
Unless*ld the Lord*s of hosts Had*ld left to us a very small remnant, We*ld would have become like Sodom, We*ld would have been made like Gomorrah.
Hear*ln the word of the Lord,*s You*ld rulers of Sodom; Give*ld ear to the law of our God, You*ld people of Gomorrah:

“To*ld what purpose is*i the multitude of your sacrifices to Me?” Says*ld the Lord.*s “I*ld have had enough of burnt offerings of rams And*ld the fat of fed cattle. I*ld do not delight in the blood of bulls, Or*ld of lambs or goats.
“When*ln you come to appear before Me, Who*ld has required this from your hand, To*ld trample My courts?
Bring*ld no more futile sacrifices; Incense*ld is an abomination to Me. The*ld New Moons, the Sabbaths, and the calling of assemblies— I*ld cannot endure iniquity and the sacred meeting.
Your*ld New Moons and your appointed feasts My*ld soul hates; They*ld are a trouble to Me, I*ld am weary of bearing them.*i
When*ld you spread out your hands, I*ld will hide My eyes from you; Even*ld though you make many prayers, I*ld will not hear. Your*ld hands are full of blood.
“Wash*ln yourselves, make yourselves clean; Put*ld away the evil of your doings from before My eyes. Cease*ld to do evil,
Learn*ld to do good; Seek*ld justice, Rebuke*ld the oppressor; Defend*ld the fatherless, Plead*ld for the widow.
“Come*ln now, and let us reason together,” Says*ld the Lord,*s “Though*ld your sins are like scarlet, They*ld shall be as white as snow; Though*ld they are red like crimson, They*ld shall be as wool.
If*ld you are willing and obedient, You*ld shall eat the good of the land;
But*ld if you refuse and rebel, You*ld shall be devoured by the sword”; For*ld the mouth of the Lord*s has spoken.
The Degenerate City
How*pn the faithful city has become a harlot! It*ld was full of justice; Righteousness*ld lodged in it, But*ld now murderers.
Your*ld silver has become dross, Your*ld wine mixed with water.

Your*ld princes are*i rebellious, And*ld companions of thieves; Everyone*ld loves bribes, And*ld follows after rewards. They*ld do not defend the fatherless, Nor*ld does the cause of the widow come before them.
Therefore*ln the Lord says, The*ld Lord*s of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel, “Ah,*ld I will rid Myself of My adversaries, And*ld take vengeance on My enemies.
I*ld will turn My hand against you, And*ld thoroughly purge away your dross, And*ld take away all your alloy.
I*ld will restore your judges as at the first, And*ld your counselors as at the beginning. Afterward*ld you shall be called the city of righteousness, the faithful city.”
Zion*ln shall be redeemed with justice, And*ld her penitents with righteousness.
The*ld destruction of transgressors and of sinners shall*i be*i together, And*ld those who forsake the Lord*s shall be consumed.
For*ld they shall be ashamed of the terebinth trees Which*ld you have desired; And*ld you shall be embarrassed because of the gardens Which*ld you have chosen.
For*ld you shall be as a terebinth whose leaf fades, And*ld as a garden that has no water.
The*ld strong shall be as tinder, And*ld the work of it as a spark; Both*ld will burn together, And*ld no one shall quench them.*i
Isaiah 2
The Future House of God
The*p word that Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

Now*pn it shall come to pass in the latter days That*ild the mountain of the Lord’s*s house Shall*ld be established on the top of the mountains, And*ld shall be exalted above the hills; And*ld all nations shall flow to it.

Many*ld people shall come and say, “Come,*ld and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,*s To*ld the house of the God of Jacob; He*ld will teach us His ways, And*ld we shall walk in His paths.” For*ld out of Zion shall go forth the law, And*ld the word of the Lord*s from Jerusalem.

He*ld shall judge between the nations, And*ld rebuke many people; They*ld shall beat their swords into plowshares, And*ld their spears into pruning hooks; Nation*ld shall not lift up sword against nation, Neither*ld shall they learn war anymore.
The Day of the Lord
O*pn house of Jacob, come and let us walk In*ld the light of the Lord.*s

For*ln You have forsaken Your people, the house of Jacob, Because*ld they are filled with eastern ways; They*ld are*i soothsayers like the Philistines, And*ld they are pleased with the children of foreigners.
Their*ld land is also full of silver and gold, And*ld there is no end to their treasures; Their*ld land is also full of horses, And*ld there is no end to their chariots.
Their*ld land is also full of idols; They*ld worship the work of their own hands, That*ld which their own fingers have made.
People*ld bow down, And*ld each man humbles himself; Therefore*ld do not forgive them.
Enter*ln into the rock, and hide in the dust, From*ld the terror of the Lord*s And*ld the glory of His majesty.
The*ld lofty looks of man shall be humbled, The*ld haughtiness of men shall be bowed down, And*ld the Lord*s alone shall be exalted in that day.
For*ln the day of the Lord*s of hosts Shall*ild come*i upon everything proud and lofty, Upon*ld everything lifted up— And*ld it shall be brought low—
Upon*ld all the cedars of Lebanon that*i are*i high and lifted up, And*ld upon all the oaks of Bashan;
Upon*ld all the high mountains, And*ld upon all the hills that*i are*i lifted up;
Upon*ld every high tower, And*ld upon every fortified wall;
Upon*ld all the ships of Tarshish, And*ld upon all the beautiful sloops.
The*ld loftiness of man shall be bowed down, And*ld the haughtiness of men shall be brought low; The*ld Lord*s alone will be exalted in that day,
But*ld the idols He shall utterly abolish.
They*ln shall go into the holes of the rocks, And*ld into the caves of the earth, From*ld the terror of the Lord*s And*ld the glory of His majesty, When*ld He arises to shake the earth mightily.
In*ln that day a man will cast away his idols of silver And*ld his idols of gold, Which*ld they made, each*i for himself to worship, To*ld the moles and bats,
To*ld go into the clefts of the rocks, And*ld into the crags of the rugged rocks, From*ld the terror of the Lord*s And*ld the glory of His majesty, When*ld He arises to shake the earth mightily.
Sever*ln yourselves from such a man, Whose*ld breath is*i in his nostrils; For*ld of what account is he?
Isaiah 3
Judgment on Judah and Jerusalem
For*pn behold, the Lord, the Lord*s of hosts, Takes*ld away from Jerusalem and from Judah The*ld stock and the store, The*ld whole supply of bread and the whole supply of water;
The*ld mighty man and the man of war, The*ld judge and the prophet, And*ld the diviner and the elder;
The*ld captain of fifty and the honorable man, The*ld counselor and the skillful artisan, And*ld the expert enchanter.
“I*ld will give children to*i be*i their princes, And*ld babes shall rule over them.
The*ld people will be oppressed, Every*ld one by another and every one by his neighbor; The*ld child will be insolent toward the elder, And*ld the base toward the honorable.”
When*ln a man takes hold of his brother In*ld the house of his father, saying,*i “You*ld have clothing; You*ld be our ruler, And*ld let*i these ruins be*i under your power,”
In*ld that day he will protest, saying, “I*ld cannot cure your*i ills, For*ld in my house is*i neither food nor clothing; Do*ld not make me a ruler of the people.”
For*ln Jerusalem stumbled, And*ld Judah is fallen, Because*ld their tongue and their doings Are*ild against the Lord,*s To*ld provoke the eyes of His glory.
The*ld look on their countenance witnesses against them, And*ld they declare their sin as Sodom; They*ld do not hide it.*i Woe*ld to their soul! For*ld they have brought evil upon themselves.
“Say*ln to the righteous that it*i shall*i be*i well with*i them,*i For*ld they shall eat the fruit of their doings.
Woe*ld to the wicked! It*i shall*i be*i ill with*i him,*i For*ld the reward of his hands shall be given him.
As*ild for*i My people, children are*i their oppressors, And*ld women rule over them. O*ld My people! Those who lead you cause you*i to err, And*ld destroy the way of your paths.”
Oppression and Luxury Condemned
The*pn Lord*s stands up to plead, And*ld stands to judge the people.
The*ld Lord*s will enter into judgment With*ld the elders of His people And*ld His princes: “For*ld you have eaten up the vineyard; The*ld plunder of the poor is*i in your houses.
What*ld do you mean by crushing My people And*ld grinding the faces of the poor?” Says*ld the Lord God*s of hosts.

Moreover*p the Lord*s says: “Because*pn the daughters of Zion are haughty, And*ld walk with outstretched necks And*ld wanton eyes, Walking*ld and mincing as*i they go, Making*ld a jingling with their feet,
Therefore*ld the Lord will strike with a scab The*ld crown of the head of the daughters of Zion, And*ld the Lord*s will uncover their secret parts.”
In*ln that day the Lord will take away the finery: The*ld jingling anklets, the scarves, and the crescents;
The*ld pendants, the bracelets, and the veils;
The*ld headdresses, the leg ornaments, and the headbands; The*ld perfume boxes, the charms,
and*ld the rings; The*ld nose jewels,
the*ld festal apparel, and the mantles; The*ld outer garments, the purses,
and*ld the mirrors; The*ld fine linen, the turbans, and the robes.

And*p so it shall be: Instead*pn of a sweet smell there will be a stench; Instead*ld of a sash, a rope; Instead*ld of well-set hair, baldness; Instead*ld of a rich robe, a girding of sackcloth; And*ld branding instead of beauty.
Your*ld men shall fall by the sword, And*ld your mighty in the war.
Her*ln gates shall lament and mourn, And*ld she being*i desolate shall sit on the ground.
Isaiah 4
And*pn in that day seven women shall take hold of one man, saying, “We*ld will eat our own food and wear our own apparel; Only*ld let us be called by your name, To*ld take away our reproach.”
The Renewal of Zion
In*pn that day the Branch of the Lord*s shall be beautiful and glorious; And*ld the fruit of the earth shall*i be*i excellent and appealing For*ld those of Israel who have escaped.
And*p it shall come to pass that he*i who*i is*i left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy—everyone who is recorded among the living in Jerusalem.
When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion, and purged the blood of Jerusalem from her midst, by the spirit of judgment and by the spirit of burning,

then the Lord*s will create above every dwelling place of Mount Zion, and above her assemblies, a cloud and smoke by day and the shining of a flaming fire by night. For over all the glory there will*i be*i a covering.
And there will be a tabernacle for shade in the daytime from the heat, for a place of refuge, and for a shelter from storm and rain.
Isaiah 5
God’s Disappointing Vineyard
Now*pn let me sing to my Well-beloved A*ld song of my Beloved regarding His vineyard: My*ln Well-beloved has a vineyard On*ld a very fruitful hill.

He*ld dug it up and cleared out its stones, And*ld planted it with the choicest vine. He*ld built a tower in its midst, And*ld also made a winepress in it; So*ld He expected it*i to bring forth good*i grapes, But*ld it brought forth wild grapes.
“And*ln now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah, Judge,*ld please, between Me and My vineyard.
What*ld more could have been done to My vineyard That*ld I have not done in it? Why*ld then, when I expected it*i to bring forth good*i grapes, Did*ld it bring forth wild grapes?
And*ld now, please let Me tell you what I will do to My vineyard: I*ld will take away its hedge, and it shall be burned; And*ild break down its wall, and it shall be trampled down.
I*ld will lay it waste; It*ld shall not be pruned or dug, But*ld there shall come up briers and thorns. I*ld will also command the clouds That*ld they rain no rain on it.”

For*ln the vineyard of the Lord*s of hosts is*i the house of Israel, And*ld the men of Judah are His pleasant plant. He*ld looked for justice, but behold, oppression; For*ld righteousness, but behold, a cry for*i help.*i
Impending Judgment on Excesses
Woe*pn to those who join house to house; They*ld add field to field, Till*ld there*i is*i no place Where*ld they may dwell alone in the midst of the land!
In*ld my hearing the Lord*s of hosts said,*i “Truly,*ld many houses shall be desolate, Great*ld and beautiful ones, without inhabitant.
For*ld ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath, And*ld a homer of seed shall yield one ephah.”
Woe*ln to those who rise early in the morning, That*ild they may follow intoxicating drink; Who*ld continue until night, till*i wine inflames them!
The*ld harp and the strings, The*ld tambourine and flute, And*ld wine are in their feasts; But*ld they do not regard the work of the Lord,*s Nor*ld consider the operation of His hands.
Therefore*ln my people have gone into captivity, Because*ld they*i have*i no knowledge; Their*ld honorable men are*i famished, And*ld their multitude dried up with thirst.
Therefore*ld Sheol has enlarged itself And*ld opened its mouth beyond measure; Their*ld glory and their multitude and their pomp, And*ld he who is jubilant, shall descend into it.
People*ld shall be brought down, Each*ld man shall be humbled, And*ld the eyes of the lofty shall be humbled.
But*ld the Lord*s of hosts shall be exalted in judgment, And*ld God who is holy shall be hallowed in righteousness.
Then*ld the lambs shall feed in their pasture, And*ld in the waste places of the fat ones strangers shall eat.
Woe*ln to those who draw iniquity with cords of vanity, And*ld sin as if with a cart rope;
That*ld say, “Let Him make speed and*i hasten His work, That*ld we may see it;*i And*ld let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw near and come, That*ld we may know it.”*i
Woe*ln to those who call evil good, and good evil; Who*ld put darkness for light, and light for darkness; Who*ld put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!
Woe*ln to those*i who*i are*i wise in their own eyes, And*ld prudent in their own sight!
Woe*ln to men mighty at drinking wine, Woe*ld to men valiant for mixing intoxicating drink,
Who*ld justify the wicked for a bribe, And*ld take away justice from the righteous man!

Therefore,*ln as the fire devours the stubble, And*ld the flame consumes the chaff, So*ild their root will be as rottenness, And*ld their blossom will ascend like dust; Because*ld they have rejected the law of the Lord*s of hosts, And*ld despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

Therefore*ld the anger of the Lord*s is aroused against His people; He*ld has stretched out His hand against them And*ld stricken them, And*ld the hills trembled. Their*ld carcasses were*i as refuse in the midst of the streets. For*ln all this His anger is not turned away, But*ld His hand is*i stretched out still.
He*ln will lift up a banner to the nations from afar, And*ld will whistle to them from the end of the earth; Surely*ld they shall come with speed, swiftly.
No*ld one will be weary or stumble among them, No*ld one will slumber or sleep; Nor*ld will the belt on their loins be loosed, Nor*ld the strap of their sandals be broken;
Whose*ld arrows are*i sharp, And*ld all their bows bent; Their*ld horses’ hooves will seem like flint, And*ld their wheels like a whirlwind.
Their*ld roaring will*i be*i like a lion, They*ld will roar like young lions; Yes,*ld they will roar And*ld lay hold of the prey; They*ld will carry it*i away safely, And*ld no one will deliver.
In*ld that day they will roar against them Like*ld the roaring of the sea. And*ld if one*i looks to the land, Behold,*ld darkness and*i sorrow; And*ld the light is darkened by the clouds.
Isaiah 6
Isaiah Called to Be a Prophet
In*p the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, high and lifted up, and the train of His robe*i filled the temple.
Above it stood seraphim; each one had six wings: with two he covered his face, with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
And one cried to another and said: “Holy,*pn holy, holy is*i the Lord*s of hosts; The*ld whole earth is*i full of His glory!”
And*p the posts of the door were shaken by the voice of him who cried out, and the house was filled with smoke.

So*p I said: “Woe*pn is*i me, for I am undone! Because*ld I am*i a man of unclean lips, And*ld I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; For*ld my eyes have seen the King, The*ld Lord*s of hosts.”
Then*p one of the seraphim flew to me, having in his hand a live coal which*i he had taken with the tongs from the altar.
And he touched my mouth with*i it,*i and said: “Behold,*pn this has touched your lips; Your*ld iniquity is taken away, And*ld your sin purged.”
Also*p I heard the voice of the Lord, saying: “Whom*pn shall I send, And*ld who will go for Us?” Then*p I said, “Here am*i I! Send me.”
And*p He said, “Go, and tell this people: ‘Keep*pn on hearing, but do not understand; Keep*ld on seeing, but do not perceive.’

“Make*ln the heart of this people dull, And*ld their ears heavy, And*ld shut their eyes; Lest*ld they see with their eyes, And*ld hear with their ears, And*ld understand with their heart, And*ld return and be healed.”
Then*p I said, “Lord, how long?” And*p He answered: “Until*pn the cities are laid waste and without inhabitant, The*ld houses are without a man, The*ld land is utterly desolate,
The*ld Lord*s has removed men far away, And*ld the forsaken places are*i many in the midst of the land.

But*ld yet a tenth will*i be*i in it, And*ld will return and be for consuming, As*ld a terebinth tree or as an oak, Whose*ld stump remains*i when it is cut down. So*ld the holy seed shall*i be*i its stump.”
Isaiah 7
Isaiah Sent to King Ahaz

Now*p it came to pass in the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that*i Rezin king of Syria and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to make*i war against it, but could not prevail against it.
And it was told to the house of David, saying, “Syria’s forces are deployed in Ephraim.” So his heart and the heart of his people were moved as the trees of the woods are moved with the wind.
Then*p the Lord*s said to Isaiah, “Go out now to meet Ahaz, you and Shear-Jashub your son, at the end of the aqueduct from the upper pool, on the highway to the Fuller’s Field,
and say to him: ‘Take heed, and be quiet; do not fear or be fainthearted for these two stubs of smoking firebrands, for the fierce anger of Rezin and Syria, and the son of Remaliah.
Because Syria, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah have plotted evil against you, saying,
“Let us go up against Judah and trouble it, and let us make a gap in its wall for ourselves, and set a king over them, the son of Tabel”—
thus says the Lord God:*s “It*pn shall not stand, Nor*ld shall it come to pass.
For*ld the head of Syria is*i Damascus, And*ld the head of Damascus is*i Rezin. Within*ld sixty-five years Ephraim will be broken, So*ild that*i it*i will*i not be*i a people.
The*ld head of Ephraim is*i Samaria, And*ld the head of Samaria is*i Remaliah’s son. If*ld you will not believe, Surely*ld you shall not be established.”’”
The Immanuel Prophecy
Moreover*p the Lord*s spoke again to Ahaz, saying,
“Ask a sign for yourself from the Lord*s your God; ask it either in the depth or in the height above.”
But*p Ahaz said, “I will not ask, nor will I test the Lord!”*s
Then*p he said, “Hear now, O house of David! Is*i it*i a small thing for you to weary men, but will you weary my God also?
Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a Son, and shall call His name Immanuel.
Curds and honey He shall eat, that He may know to refuse the evil and choose the good.
For before the Child shall know to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land that you dread will be forsaken by both her kings.
The Lord*s will bring the king of Assyria upon you and your people and your father’s house—days that have not come since the day that Ephraim departed from Judah.”
And*pn it shall come to pass in that day That*ild the Lord*s will whistle for the fly That*ld is*i in the farthest part of the rivers of Egypt, And*ld for the bee that is*i in the land of Assyria.
They*ld will come, and all of them will rest In*ld the desolate valleys and in the clefts of the rocks, And*ld on all thorns and in all pastures.
In*ln the same day the Lord will shave with a hired razor, With*ld those from beyond the River, with the king of Assyria, The*ld head and the hair of the legs, And*ld will also remove the beard.
It*ln shall be in that day That*ild a man will keep alive a young cow and two sheep;
So*ld it shall be, from the abundance of milk they give, That*ld he will eat curds; For*ld curds and honey everyone will eat who is left in the land.
It*ln shall happen in that day, That*ild wherever there could be a thousand vines Worth*ild a thousand shekels*i of silver, It*ld will be for briers and thorns.
With*ld arrows and bows men*i will come there, Because*ld all the land will become briers and thorns.
And*ln to any hill which could be dug with the hoe, You*ld will not go there for fear of briers and thorns; But*ld it will become a range for oxen And*ld a place for sheep to roam.
Isaiah 8
Assyria Will Invade the Land
Moreover*p the Lord*s said to me, “Take a large scroll, and write on it with a man’s pen concerning Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.
And I will take for Myself faithful witnesses to record, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.”
Then*p I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord*s said to me, “Call his name Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz;
for before the child shall have knowledge to cry ‘My father’ and ‘My mother,’ the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken away before the king of Assyria.”
The*p Lord*s also spoke to me again, saying:
“Inasmuch*pn as these people refused The*ld waters of Shiloah that flow softly, And*ld rejoice in Rezin and in Remaliah’s son;

Now*ld therefore, behold, the Lord brings up over them The*ld waters of the River, strong and mighty— The*ld king of Assyria and all his glory; He*ld will go up over all his channels And*ld go over all his banks.
He*ld will pass through Judah, He*ld will overflow and pass over, He*ld will reach up to the neck; And*ld the stretching out of his wings Will*ld fill the breadth of Your land, O Immanuel.
“Be*ln shattered, O you peoples, and be broken in pieces! Give*ld ear, all you from far countries. Gird*ld yourselves, but be broken in pieces; Gird*ld yourselves, but be broken in pieces.
Take*ld counsel together, but it will come to nothing; Speak*ld the word, but it will not stand, For*ld God is*i with us.”
Fear God, Heed His Word
For*p the Lord*s spoke thus to me with a strong hand, and instructed me that I should not walk in the way of this people, saying:
“Do*pn not say, ‘A conspiracy,’ Concerning*ld all that this people call a conspiracy, Nor*ld be afraid of their threats, nor be troubled.
The*ld Lord*s of hosts, Him you shall hallow; Let*ild Him be*i your fear, And*ld let*i Him be*i your dread.
He*ld will be as a sanctuary, But*ld a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense To*ld both the houses of Israel, As*ld a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
And*ld many among them shall stumble; They*ld shall fall and be broken, Be*ld snared and taken.”
Bind*ln up the testimony, Seal*ld the law among my disciples.
And*ld I will wait on the Lord,*s Who*ld hides His face from the house of Jacob; And*ld I will hope in Him.
Here*ld am I and the children whom the Lord*s has given me! We*ild are for signs and wonders in Israel From*ld the Lord*s of hosts, Who*ld dwells in Mount Zion.
And*p when they say to you, “Seek those who are mediums and wizards, who whisper and mutter,” should not a people seek their God? Should*i they*i seek the dead on behalf of the living?
To the law and to the testimony! If they do not speak according to this word, it*i is*i because there is no light in them.
They*p will pass through it hard-pressed and hungry; and it shall happen, when they are hungry, that they will be enraged and curse their king and their God, and look upward.
Then they will look to the earth, and see trouble and darkness, gloom of anguish; and they*i will*i be*i driven into darkness.
Isaiah 9
The Government of the Promised Son

Nevertheless*pn the gloom will*i not be*i upon her who is*i distressed, As*ld when at first He lightly esteemed The*ld land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, And*ld afterward more heavily oppressed her,*i By*ild the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, In*ld Galilee of the Gentiles.
The*ld people who walked in darkness Have*ld seen a great light; Those*ld who dwelt in the land of the shadow of death, Upon*ld them a light has shined.
You*ln have multiplied the nation And*ild increased its joy; They*ld rejoice before You According*ld to the joy of harvest, As*ld men*i rejoice when they divide the spoil.
For*ld You have broken the yoke of his burden And*ld the staff of his shoulder, The*ld rod of his oppressor, As*ld in the day of Midian.
For*ld every warrior’s sandal from the noisy battle, And*ld garments rolled in blood, Will*ld be used for burning and*i fuel of fire.

For*ln unto us a Child is born, Unto*ld us a Son is given; And*ld the government will be upon His shoulder. And*ld His name will be called Wonderful,*ld Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting*ld Father, Prince of Peace.

Of*ld the increase of His*i government and peace There*ild will*i be*i no end, Upon*ld the throne of David and over His kingdom, To*ld order it and establish it with judgment and justice From*ld that time forward, even forever. The*ld zeal of the Lord*s of hosts will perform this.
The Punishment of Samaria
The*pn Lord sent a word against Jacob, And*ld it has fallen on Israel.
All*ld the people will know— Ephraim*ld and the inhabitant of Samaria— Who*ld say in pride and arrogance of heart:
“The*ld bricks have fallen down, But*ld we will rebuild with hewn stones; The*ld sycamores are cut down, But*ld we will replace them*i with cedars.”
Therefore*ld the Lord*s shall set up The*ld adversaries of Rezin against him, And*ld spur his enemies on,
The*ld Syrians before and the Philistines behind; And*ld they shall devour Israel with an open mouth. For*ln all this His anger is not turned away, But*ld His hand is*i stretched out still.
